QuestionText: A particle moves along a straight line OX. At a time $t$ (in seconds) the distance $x$ (in metres) of the particle from O is given by $x = 40 + 12t - t^3$. How long would the particle travel before coming to rest?
explanationText: Given $x = 40 + 12t - t^3$. Velocity $v = \frac{dx}{dt} = 12 - 3t^2$. The particle comes to rest when $v=0$, so $12 - 3t^2 = 0 \Rightarrow t^2 = 4 \Rightarrow t = 2$ s (since $t>0$). Distance travelled in 2s: $x(2) - x(0) = (40 + 12(2) - 2^3) - (40 + 12(0) - 0^3) = (40 + 24 - 8) - 40 = 56 - 40 = 16 \text{ m}$.

QuestionText: A car travels the first half of a distance between two places at a speed of $30 \text{ km/h}$ and the second half of the distance at $50 \text{ km/h}$. The average speed of the car for the whole journey is:
explanationText: Let the total distance be $2d$. Time taken for the first half $t_1 = \frac{d}{30}$. Time taken for the second half $t_2 = \frac{d}{50}$. Total time $T = t_1 + t_2 = d(\frac{1}{30} + \frac{1}{50}) = d(\frac{5+3}{150}) = \frac{8d}{150}$. Average speed $= \frac{\text{Total distance}}{\text{Total time}} = \frac{2d}{8d/150} = \frac{2 \times 150}{8} = \frac{300}{8} = 37.5 \text{ km/h}$.
